title: Tuesday, 15th December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Hopefully the tech is working

PM

Im still sick

11:02 am
PM

And feeling very sorry for myself

PM

The lurgy has mutated

PM

Anyway, we're all jsut hanging around, waiting for Janet

11:02 am
PM

Guess it means we dig out this pic

PM

Waiting for lift off

PM

It's not going to be "lift off" anyway -- as in rates are going to nudge higher and sit there

11:03 am
PM

Not exactly space travel

PM

Anyway, here's the guys waiting for Janet

PM

11:04 am
PM

Does anyone out there have the slightest idea why the Footsie is up 1.7%

PM

Anyone?

PM

Vague ideas?

11:04 am
PM

Nuts

BE

Down eight days, up one.

PM

CPI above 0%?

11:04 am
PM

Have we been down 8 days?

PM

Hadn't clocked that

PM

Was in sick bed

11:05 am
BE

Yup. It's down for eight days so it goes up for one. And with that, we can close.

BE

See you tomorrow, everyone. Bye.

PM

Thanks Rabble

11:05 am
PM

Cheer Bryce

undefined
BE

Actually, there are a few things to note.

11:05 am
AVEVA Group PLC (AVV:LSE): Last: 1,438, down 728 (-33.61%), High: 1,493, Low: 1,355, Volume: 645.81k
BE

..... for example.

PM

scorchedfingers

11:06 am
BE

Market didn't quite arb the risk-reward here terribly efficiently.

PM

Did no one see the risks in this deal?

BE

Well, can I quote something here?

11:06 am
PM

sure

BE

It is important to know that the risk of the deal being cancelled is realistic, especially considering the fact that at the time of the offer, Schneider’s software assets would have been valued (benchmarked) on the back of AVEVA’s valuation.
Therefore, at the time of the deal announcement, the average three-month share price for AVEVA was GB18.43. At 74m shares that Schneider would obtain as per the offered value, this implied that Schneider considered that the group was worth GBP1.364bn. For that, Schneider was willing to pay GBP550m, which implies that it valued its own software business at GBP814m. This would translate into a 2.5x sales multiple and is probably reasonable, considering the nature of the business, its growth prospects and the potential synergies.
However, with the current valuation of GBP12 (ex-cash payment), the new AVEVA/Schneider software group is valued at GBP888m. If we deduct the cash payment that Schneider has to make, then Schneider’s software assets are currently valued at GBP338m or c1x sales.
This is arguably too low and if Schneider does not believe that the share price of the joint group will significantly increase after the merger, we believe that there is a high probability of the deal being cancelled (especially as there is no break fee).

BE

That was written by Daud Khan at Berenberg, on September 23rd.

11:06 am
BE

When everyone else on the sellside was talking about a potential counter.

BE

I note it because Daud and his colleague Adaan Ahmad were let go last week.

BE

Which seemed a pretty stupid decision at the time. Even more so now.

11:07 am
PM

Indeed!

PM

Bring back Daud and Adaan

PM

Actually, we could offer them a writing platform while they are 'resting'

11:08 am
BE

They'll go buyside, I'll wager. Probably to a long-short, as Daud's record of pulling the wings off Autonomy might be useful on the short side.

BE

Anyway, what's happened here is that Schneider's share price collapsed and blew apart the accretion argument of spinning out Invensys.

BE

Management on the tape this morning talking about costs and complexities.

11:09 am
BE

Yeah, to a point. Mostly, though, the maths fell apart.

BE

Cazenove takes us though the detail.

BE

Aveva has announced the termination of talks with Schneider Electric, by mutual consent. Aveva pointed to integration challenges that could not be overcome without considerable additional risk and cost. The Board determined that “the anticipated uplift in shareholder value was unlikely to have been realized to the extent previously considered.” The press release also said full year outlook unchanged and current trading in line. Our price target and valuation on Aveva had been based on the Schneider deal closing, and thus we are now reducing our PT to 1,500p (previously 2,450p), a level that reflects Aveva stand alone.

11:10 am
BE

· Termination of talks with Schneider. Aveva’s press release pointed to the highly complex structure of the proposed transaction, and integration challenges that would alter the perceived potential value of the deal. Bloomberg quoted CEO Richard Longdon as saying the “costs of disentangling the (Schneider) business was too high”, and that there were “too many risks in the combination”. However, he also said that the industrial logic for the deal was still there. Schneider’s press release said “no agreement could be reached on the terms of transaction”, more directly highlighting price as a sticking point (and possibly concerns around adding exposure to Oil & Gas at this time). Terms of the transaction were non-binding and no break fees are payable by either party.

BE

· M&A not completely off the table. Bloomberg reported that the CEO said in a phone interview that the M&A search could resume, and the company may go back to old talks. While the company is not actively up for sale, we believe the lower share price could bring new interested parties.
· Trading update. Full year outlook remains unchanged, and trading has continued in line since interim results in November. Our model did not include Schneider, and thus remains unchanged.

BE

· The H1 earnings update in November was weak as expected given oil price and weak E&P capex trends. Aveva reported an H1 revenue decline of 1% LFL (-5% as reported), and PBT of £10.2m was weak relative to consensus, declining by 20% organic cc due to higher operating expenses, which came from wage inflation and recruitment last year.

11:10 am
BE

In terms of the "in play" theory .....

BE

.... you can make up your own rumour by picking from the following list: Siemens, ABB, Emerson, Hexagon, Honeywell, GE, Rockwell Automation, Yokogowa.

PM

Not many people buying this counter bid line tho -- with the stock off 34%

11:12 am
BE

Precisely. We've been hearing at least two of those have had a look, then did nothing. And given the fragility of Aveva's order book, there's not much risk involved with waiting.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse .....

BE

■ What about the auction?: A number of investors have been wondering about the prospects of a third party entering an auction process. We think any possible third party interest would have waited for the deal prospectus to be published before showing their hand. Consequently, another potential bid is still a possibility, but it seems likely that much of the bid premium in the AVEVA valuation will fall away today.
■ Valuation: We are encouraged that current trading remains in line at AVEVA, in spite of the difficult end market and potential uncertainty caused by the bid process. On unchanged numbers, and on last night's close, the shares traded on a Dec 16E PE of 25x. Prior to the deal, the shares were at c£17-18, which is closer to 20x. That seems a more realistic medium term level, but there is always a risk that the shares undershoot in the short term

11:13 am
BE

A reminder that the Aveva bid rumours pre the Schneider reverse were likely to be crossed lines, mixed with management's rather selective approach to the truth.

PM

???

PM

management's rather selective approach to the truth.?

11:14 am
PM

That's a tad aggressive Bryce

BE

I'd suggest otherwise. There were widely reported rumour was that Schneider was in talks to buy Aveva ..... Shares up 15% a session ....

BE

....... What was happening was that Schneider was in talks to reverse into Aveva.

11:14 am
PM

ok ok

BE

That seems a granular difference. Still don't understand why the Panel let them say nothing.

PM

I was misunderstanding what you were referring to

11:16 am
BE

Want Goldman's Machine-To-Machine research update? Not for human consumption?

BE

You're getting it anyway.

BE

Analysis
While the company indicated that the outlook for the full year remains
unchanged post termination of the deal, we believe risks to estimates
particularly on the top line have not fully cleared given a weak end-market
outlook in Oil & Gas (35%-40% of revenue mix). Management had also
indicated during the interim results that there has been an increased push
for diversification in end-markets to address new segments like food
processing and building information management (BIM); however, we
believe this would not be enough to offset headwinds from Oil & Gas end-
market conditions.
Implications
Aveva’s share price is down c.35%, following the press release today. We
note that Aveva’s share price prior to today’s announcement was below
the level we believe incorporated the value of the transaction (see Aveva:
Announces deal with Schneider; raise PT, upgrade to Neutral, July 27,
2015) which we believe likely reflects some skepticism in the market
around completion of the deal.
Our current 12-month price target of 2,400p includes the implied value of
potential cash dividends related to the deal and the present value of cost
synergies (which we estimated to be 1,150p/share). We place our price
target under review.

11:16 am
BE

There. And let's move on.

undefined
BE

Best note the supermarkets.

11:17 am
BE

All of whom are up on the Kantar figures.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 246.60, up 9.7 (+4.09%), High: 249.20, Low: 237.10, Volume: 3.19m
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 147.70, up 4.65 (+3.25%), High: 148.85, Low: 143.10, Volume: 8.78m
11:18 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 146.40, up 6.2 (+4.42%), High: 147.70, Low: 140.70, Volume: 5.20m
BE

... though search me what's positive in there.

BE

Sainsbury's the best of them, share up by 0.2%

11:18 am
BE

Till roll growth was +1.2% YoY

BE

Tesco's market share fell just 1.0% in the three months, which is apparently good news.

PM

And this discounters?

11:19 am
PM

(I note that Clive Black has been on a Lidl mission in east London...)

BE

Oh, the usual. Lidl and Aldi 17.9% and 15.4% till roll growth.

BE

Which is a marginal slowdown, but so marginal it's likely to just be data noise.

11:20 am
PM

A par from Clive...

PM

Shore Capital visited Lidl's new store at Stratford Mall (east London) and we have to say it was excellent; particularly simple set out British fresh produce, excellent low level chilled British fresh meat, strong chilled & frozen De Luxe premium private label lines for the festive period and excellent low and mid priced wines (the latter of which has done much to broaden Lidl's brand appeal from an income perspective to our minds). More to the point the extensive queues and trolley shopper spoke volumes.

PM

excellent low level chilled British fresh meat,

11:21 am
PM

What the hell is that?

BE

Uh, dunno.

BE

(@Boncoeur: "seabass" is a broad church. You might not be comparing like with like.)

11:22 am
BE

Morgan Stanley as well.

BE

Deflation worsening sequentially: It stood at -1.9% YoY over 12wks vs. -
1.7% in P11, suggesting price pressures are not abating yet. We continue to
expect a deflationary environment over the next quarters, in part because the
price gap between the Big 4 and the discounters (~15%) remains
unsustainably high, and because of the uncertainty around Asda's reaction to
record poor sales.
Sainsbury remains the clear outperformer among the Big 4... In the 4
weeks to December 6th, Sainsbury outperformed the market by 168 bps, (vs.
+162 bps in P11 and +13 bps in P10). Looking at the last 12 weeks of Kantar
data, Sainsbury gained 20bps of market share and as such stands out as the
only Big 4 player gaining share since October 2014. Sainsbury's like-for-like
sales in Q3 are currently running around flat (+0.3%) as implied by the Kantar
data, which contrasts with consensus expectations of a ~1% decline, we
believe.

BE

... while performance remains disappointing at both Morrisons and
Tesco: Both players continued to underperform the market, albeit at a slightly
slower pace than in previous periods. Morrisons underperformed by 90 bps
(vs. -385 bps in P11 and -135 bps in P10). Tesco underperformed by 300 bps
(vs. 365 bps in P11 and 390 bps in P10). We note that both retailers were
highly promotional last year and that they are actively coming off their
couponing. Kantar data implies that Morrisons and Tesco LFL sales should
come in at respectively -0.1% and -3.0% in the current quarter (3Q for Tesco
and 4Q for Morrisons). This compares with consensus estimates of
approximately -2% for both retailers.
Asda continues to face the greatest pressure in UK grocery, with another
very poor performance (-360bps vs market). Asda remains the worst
performing Top 9 grocer, as per both Kantar and Nielsen. Kantar data implies a
negative LFL sales contraction of -4.6% in 4Q, as bad as 2Q and 3Q. We believe
that Asda has been protecting its P&L this year at the expense of its market
share and this has translated into a significant deterioration of its price
position (see pricing survey published yesterday here here ). We expect Walmart
(covered by Simeon Gutman) to react in 1H16 and this could be significantly
disruptive for the rest of the industry. As discussed in our Walmart note note
published today, should Asda decide to sacrifice 200 bps of operating margin
(which stood at 5.3% in calendar 2014) to drive market share gains, that could
potentially wipe out half of the industry's profit pool.

11:22 am
BE

Polarisation continues, albeit at a slightly slower pace : On aggregate,
the Big 4 underperformed the market by 175 bps in November, vs. -250 bps in
both P11 and P10. This is mainly due to the fact that Aldi and Lidl's combined
sales have slowed down to +14% in November, from +18% in both P11 and
P10. Waitrose' sales also slowed down a bit in November, up only +0.7% yoy
(vs. +4.9% in P11 and +2.4% in P10).

PM

I'm still pondering seabass being a broad church

PM

Can that really be the case?

11:23 am
BE

Yeah, there's like 400 species of actual seabass. .....

PM

oh

BE

11:24 am

Your seabass might well be Patagonian toothfish.

PM

PM

11:24 am
BE

Fish is a bloody nightmare, in terms of taxonomy.

PM

PM

Nothing like a bloody seabass

11:25 am
BE

(@BT: far from. I just pick my battles carefully.)

undefined
BE

Some mention of miners on the right, inevitably.

11:26 am
BE

There's a slew of 2016 previews out this morning.

BE

Unsure which one to share first. Macquarie first, perhaps?

PM

sure

11:27 am
BE

Because they've downgraded Anglo. They held fire until it fell to a sixteen-year low, then downgraded.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 282.75, up 1.95 (+0.69%), High: 291.50, Low: 282.25, Volume: 4.26m
PM

Welcome

11:28 am
BE

As our Economics team has noted, global GDP growth is expected to remain
below trend (2.8% in 2016/17) due to high levels of leverage, demographic
headwinds, low productivity growth and sub-optimal policy making. Global IP is
expected to grow only 2.3% in 2016 – a level that has historically been
consistent with low metals demand growth. In China, the commodity intensity of
economic growth will continue to fall as FAI growth is forecast to contract further
in 2016 to 8% YoY from 10% in 2015. Given infrastructure investment is set to
exceed US$2tn in 2015, it is becoming harder to maintain above trend growth,
especially with tightened local government financing and slowing land sales.
New housing starts are also expected to fall another 10% yoy in 2016 given the
inventory overhang in lower-tiered cities

BE

Capex and opex need to fall further in 2016 and loss making operations curtailed
if the miners are to contain swelling balance sheets as free cash flow generation
contracts towards, or below, zero. The handful of miners still paying dividends
will also be forced to review those capital commitments under our new forecasts.
Companies with credible debt reduction plans, strong(er) balance sheets or
compelling catalysts are best placed to weather the tough conditions ahead. For
this reason, we maintain our preference for GLEN over AAL while RIO’s superior
dividend cover and lower gearing offers slightly more protection than BHP.
Transformative growth stories, such as KAZ Minerals, should also hold up better
than some peers, provided commissioning and ramp-up targets are met while
downstream names such as Aurubis should prove relatively resilient. Amongst
the gold and gem stocks, Gemfields and Centamin offer rare earnings and cash
flow growth at compelling valuations. We remain structurally underweight steels.

BE

And on AAL ........

11:28 am
BE

Anglo American – downgraded to Underperform; TP cut to £2.50. Apart from cutting the
dividend, the restructuring plan announced last week was long on promises but short on
action. At the core of the renewed strategy is a dramatic downsizing of assets and workforce
through a combination of closure, consolidation and divestment. We believe the targeted
$2.1bn of cost reductions to 2017 will be harder to come by as Anglo is already in year three
of a cost-out drive and divestment for value is likely to be difficult in the current price
environment. There are also significant barriers to exit (especially in South Africa), costs
associated with asset closure and retrenchments that need to be factored in which leads us to
believe that it may take longer than expected to execute on the strategy. Notwithstanding our
subdued prognosis, we do not expect Anglo to raise capital in 2016. At spot prices Anglo
generates negative FCF of ~$1.0bn. However, with low debt maturities, ~$6.0bn in cash and
~$7.9bn in undrawn facilities, Anglo is sufficiently capitalised to weather a period of
depressed commodity prices.

BE

South32 also downgraded, having been a disaster since spinoff.

BE

Up 1.5% today. Think it's down about 70% since BHP spun it off to release hidden value.

11:30 am
BE

South32 – downgraded to Neutral; TP cut to £0.50. We have cut our price forecasts for
S32’s key commodities – thermal coal, manganese, aluminium, silver – by more than 20% on aggregate over the next few years. This has materially reduced our projected earnings and cash flow profile for the stock to the point where we can no longer justify an Outperform rating and therefore downgrade the stock to Neutral with a new TP of £0.50. S32 is exposed to commodities with some of the most challenged fundamentals across the complex and the
economic viability of many of its core assets, including SA Manganese, Illawarra and Cerro
Matoso, is being called into question. Decisive management action will be required to remove cash flow drag from the business in the months ahead and we struggle to identify any positive catalysts to lift the stock beyond our new TP

BE

Elsewhere!

BE

Credit Suisse pushing BHP ....

11:30 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 687.00, up 17.7 (+2.64%), High: 696.80, Low: 681.30, Volume: 3.77m
BE

... On drastically lowered forecasts. The argument, as usual, is that if you have to buy anything it may as well be BHP.

BE

the global mining sector is reaching multi-decade lows across a
range of performance and valuation metrics; however, we predict another
year of weak Chinese demand in 2016, and supply curtailments are likely to
remain too little too late, particularly in bulks. A ceiling on the US$ and floor
on oil prices will be critical in putting a floor on prices, but our strategists
expect ongoing albeit slower appreciation of the US$ in 2016. The potential
for RMB depreciation is a further macro threat in 2016.

11:31 am
BE

Cutting commodity and earnings estimates: We retain our preference for
base metals over bulks (iron ore and coal), although even in base metals
further production curtailments may still be required to firmly push markets
back into balance. In bulks the threat has moved increasingly from supply to
demand, and we expect another year of negative steel demand growth from
China in 2016;

BE

Large caps – upgrade BHP to Outperform: In a separate note we upgrade
BHP from N to OP. We now model a 50% cut in the progressive dividend to
a more sustainable level, but this still leaves the stock on an attractive 5.5%
yield. Following a 30%+ fall in the share prices, valuation is now at more
than a 15% discount to RIO and while the Samarco situation will take years
before the final cost and outcome is known we think the shares have more
than priced in a worst case scenario. GLEN (restricted) delivered a
confident update last week and continues to offer the strongest cash flows
and deleveraging from the majors underpinned by the less cyclical trading
business. RIO (N) has been the top performer YTD and will remain a
defensive name to own however we are negative on the outlook for its two
largest commodities aluminium and iron ore and RIO suffers the largest
2016 earnings downgrades under our revised prices. Under a bear scenario
for iron ore, pressure could also mount on RIO's progressive dividend.
Anglo (N) underwhelmed at its recent investor update, and we fear that the
proposed restructuring to be fully announced in February could take an
extended period of time to be delivered.

BE

And finally, Caz pushing Glencore.

11:31 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 83.10, up 3.1 (+3.88%), High: 85.19, Low: 81.76, Volume: 31.32m
PM

Brave of them

BE

Argument is that it's cheap enough.

11:33 am
BE

It's been kicked enough. Leave it.

BE

Glencore and Anglo American provided strategy updates last week. In our view, GLEN defined a credible strategy to generate $2.3bn of positive FCF in 2016, reverse balance sheet risk and create value for equity holders at spot commodity prices. AAL’s outlook is less positive, it will generate -$1bn FCF and YE’16 ND/EBITDA will stretch to 3.8x at spot prices. We estimate GLEN is the only diversified miner with positive cash flow in 2016 at spot prices (12% FCF yield). GLEN now shows attractive valuation support, with an implied market value for Industrial of less than 4x EV/EBITDA in 2016 on both spot and bearish JPMe prices. We upgrade GLEN to OW on an unchanged £1.60/sh Dec’16 PT. We remain UW on AAL with a £2.65/sh Dec’16 PT.

BE

· GLEN offers credible route to $2.3bn FCF: The key surprise at the investor day was the extent of cost cutting in Zinc, Copper & Coal, which drives a $2.0bn uplift in our 2016E EBITDA to $7.6bn at current prices. Outlined opex and capex savings add £0.29/sh to our NPV 2016-20. We estimate $3.2bn FCF pre-working capital across 2016-17 (guidance $2.3bn in 2016), rising to $5.6bn post released working capital. We estimate GLEN will generate positive FCF across 2016-17 unless spot prices fall greater than 20%.
· $18-19bn ND target at YE’16 addresses our key concern: GLEN is accelerating debt reduction and its $18-19bn target at YE’16 is ~$4-5bn lower than our previous estimate. Prior to the strategy update, we estimated a ~$15bn capital shortfall for a BBB/Baa2 credit rating YE’16, but more aggressive cost savings now see this less than $1bn at spot prices. A scenario at spot -10% implies a gap of ~$9bn, but an investment grade credit rating could be defended by more aggressive disposals. We see upside to GLEN’s $3-4bn disposal target and we highlight we value 100% of Agriculture at $8.0bn.

11:33 am
BE

· AAL strategy faces significant hurdles: AAL effectively outlined two strategies. The strategy of the last two years has been beefed up slightly, but still delivers a -12% FCF yield in 2016 at spot (-36% at spot -10%) and a ~$4bn capital shortfall for an investment grade credit rating. The one they would like to pursue, shrinking employees and assets 66% but retaining 66% of EBITDA, will involve delicate negotiations with a range of stakeholders, including the South African government.
· Upgrade GLEN to OW, an interesting alternative to RIO: Whilst we retain concerns over the long term impact of aggressive cost cutting and the risk to its balance sheet at lower prices, GLEN’s decisive measures credibly mitigate the risk of dilution for equity holders, in our view. In contrast, AAL's excessive leverage means this risk should continue to grow as we head into 2016.

BE

So that's probably enough grey on the miners. Too much, some would argue.

undefined
11:34 am
PM

had you looked at this FCA fine on Threadneedle?

PM

£6m for crap internal controls

BE

Hadn't. Which Threadneedle?

11:34 am
PM

Which just looks like a regular regulators tax

PM

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has fined Threadneedle Asset Management Limited (TAML) £6,038,504 for failing to put in place adequate controls in the fixed income area of its front office, and for providing inaccurate information to the regulator and for failing to correct the inaccurate representation for four months.

PM

You'd generally ignore it except for...

11:35 am
PM

Shortly after TAML submitted its response, a fund manager on the Emerging Markets Debt desk initiated, executed and booked a $150 million trade on behalf of TAML funds at four times its market value. The fund manager did not have the authority to make the trade. TAML’s outsourced back office identified the problem and did not settle the trade.

PM

The FCA considers these failings to be particularly serious because the deficiencies allowed a fund manager to initiate, execute and book a $150 million trade which, had it settled, could have caused a $110 million loss to the relevant client funds.

PM

That sounds a tad incompetent

11:36 am
PM

So go and look at the Final Notice...

PM

And it gets weirder

PM

Approximately one month after the Firm submitted the RMP Response, on 3
August 2011, a fund manager on the Emerging Markets desk initiated, executed
and booked a $150 million trade to purchase Argentine warrants on behalf of
three Threadneedle funds at four times their market value (“Unauthorised
Transaction”). The fund manager was neither the manager of the funds nor did
he have authority to make the trades.

11:36 am
PM

Argentine warrants?

PM

Pretty spicy, eh?

PM

And then...

11:37 am
PM

TAML’s back office prevented the Unauthorised Transaction from settling. Had
the Unauthorised Transaction settled, it could have exposed the funds to a £70
million loss. Other parties were involved in the transaction which was part of a
wider matter. That matter was the subject of High Court proceedings in which it
was noted that there had been an intended fraud upon TAML. The Firm may have
been obliged to compensate the funds for the loss requiring it to call on its
insurance cover. The Unauthorised Transaction led the Authority to ask the Firm
to submit a report identifying the processes and controls in place at the time of
the Unauthorised Transaction. Following that, on 28 October 2011, TAML
informed the Authority that the RMP Response “did not fully reflect” the actual
dealing practice on the Emerging Market and High Yield desks and apologised
“unreservedly for this”.

PM

It's seems there was an attempted fraud here, allegedly

PM

I don't think we knew anything about that

11:38 am
PM

Anyway, another 27 pages here: http://www.fca.org...set-management.pdf

undefined
BE

So this Liberum downgrade of Supergroup has been mentioned.

11:39 am
BE

Largely, it says what anyone who owns the stock should be checking on habitually.

BE

As in, there's rather a lot of clothes going into the sales channel.

BE

Which they shouldn't be, as the whole Idris Elba relaunch and that stuff is supposed to have broadened the brand.

11:40 am
PM

(Thanks Mouselet)

BE

As ever, we note you can see current Superdry surplus stock levels just by drifting around its Ebay store: http://stores.ebay...The-Superdry-Store

BE

1k+ mens' tee-shirts in there as of this morning. That's 1k designs, unknown quantities of each.

11:42 am
PM

1k designs? really?

BE

Yup. And as ever, we note that for a brand that doesn't discount, it does a lot of discounting.

BE

Liberum says ........

11:42 am
BE

We upgraded TP and forecasts on 6 November but today move to HOLD. Investors will quite rightly ask what has changed. We caveated our upgrade with concerns over inventory and increasing competition; since then we note promotional activity in stores and online, no more than last year, but off what should be a more solid trading base. The shares are up 85% since we upgraded to a BUY last December. The moment has come to take profits. HOLD

BE

We know the good news…

H1 sales were strong but scope for positive surprises is limited. H1 retail sales grow 17% vs a -12% decline in the prior year while H2 comps are +4%, a tougher hurdle.

Catalysts

We will check H1 stock levels at the interims on 16 Dec and expect improvement on the 52% stock/sales ratio last year. We look for flat to small positive Retail LFL sales at the Christmas trading update in January.

Tougher competition
SGP has promotions at 20% off. Nearby we found Gap at 50% off and H&M up to 60%, among others. Mild weather means too much inventory across clothing, we believe.

Valuation

SGP trades at a 50% premium to its long term average PE. In the absence of positive catalysts we see more downside risk. We downgrade our TP to 1500p, a 33% premium to the long term average.

BE

Liberum's research took it as far as St Paul's

11:44 am
BE

undefined
PM

Liberum based at Ropemaker st btw

11:46 am
PM

Give 5 min walk to St Pauls

BE

Yup, they're quite near Barbican.

BE

PM

(Why?)

BE

Interims are frankly terrible, with all revenue lines disappointing and the only small positive being opex base growth (+2%) ahead of our expectation (+6%) limiting the damage slightly, leading to a £7m loss at EBIT level instead of our forecast £4m loss. At first sight, revised EBIT for FY16E is likely to be £5m-£10m versus our current £19m. Most alarming in the results is MIPS volumes down materially yoy, having seemed to be on the path to recovery through FY15. GPU volumes are also down, but this is more traceable (to Intel).
While these numbers are (spectacularly) bad, Imagination has been reporting weak numbers for several years, with four consecutive years of EBIT decline including FY16E. Despite this, the underlying business is IP-rich and in our view should in theory be capable of a 30%-40% EBIT margin. Sources of initial improvement look obvious - shut Pure, a business with no connection to the core that has lost money for 8 consecutive years (this would be very EPS accretive), and cut what we consider to be ridiculous levels of R&D.
The force majeure risk remains that Apple adopts its own GPU; at greater than 30% of revenue, this would be deeply damaging for Imagination. This is a story that occasionally circulates, and cropped up again in the media last week, but we think it most likely that Apple is hiring GPU engineers to edit IMG IP, similar to the work on ARM’s CPU IP.
In our view, the catalyst for change exists in the form of the new(ish) Chairman, whose history suggests that the necessary changes will ultimately be made (Vestas Wind Systems). Versus a long term trend 5x EV/Sales multiple, Imagination currently sits at a huge discount, reflecting margin destruction in recent years, with a decimated share price. We therefore remain at Buy despite these results reinforcing Imagination’s position as a “special sit”.

11:55 am
BE

Cutting estimates. Factoring in the significant 1H loss and FY16 adj.-EBIT now expected to be below previous expectations, we cut our FY16 adj.-EBIT estimates c.50%. FY17 Adj.-EBIT estimates also come down materially to bring us more in line, from the top-end of consensus previously.

Why remain buyers? With IMG’s stock down c.-35% in the last 3 months (vs FTSE Small-Cap -3%), today’s weak print has largely been priced in. We still believe there’s value within an interesting collection of semiconductor IP assets. We see at least c.200p of value if the current non-Pure businesses could achieve a peer EBIT margin of 30%. To us, this highlights the importance of IMG maintaining focus on achieving its 30-40% op margin target.

Valuation/Risks
We value IMG at the top-end of a 25-35x P/E (FY17E) range (discount to premium peer ARM). We use a top-end rating to reflect that the full leverage benefits of royalty volumes are to come through in future years. Risks; uncertainties over MIPS delivery, end customer design-wins/volumes and competitor moves.

BE

Carpetright (HOLD) – Interim results (figures better than expected but forecast remains unchanged)
CPR LN (469p, TP 470p), Market Cap: £319m

Our View: The interim results were better than our expectations despite a decline in the gross margins due to lower than forecast rental charges. The second half might be tougher as the company is now coming up against the anniversary of the interest free credit offer and competition is growing from the new Tapi concept. The stock remains highly valued. We retain our HOLD recommendation and our TP of 470p.
· Profits were ahead of our expectations – Underlying pre-tax profits for the six months to end of October increased by 34% to £9.0m vs. CFE Research £8.2m on sales up by 1.4% to £231m. Exceptionals totalled £1.9m and related to onerous lease charges and store closure costs. In the UK, underlying operating profits rose by 29% to £9.4m vs. CFE Research £7.7m benefiting from lower rental costs as a result of the company’s store closure programme on LFL sales of 3.7% while in Europe, operating profits were £0.6m vs. CFE Research £1.0m. Gross margins were reported to have declined by 70bps, broadly in line with our expectations. Net cash came in at £4m, an improvement of £1m against the previous year. There is no comment on current trade apart from management’s expectations of achieving current market expectations.

· No change to our forecasts – Following this update, we are retaining our ‘top of the range’ FY2016 pre-tax profit forecast of £18m (EPS: 20.1p).

· One or two concerns still on the horizon – The strategy being implemented by Wilf Walsh is credible but is not enough, in our view, to move the dial. The company has benefited from offering interest free credit in the last year and a more positive upturn in housing transactions and consumer confidence. It is, we believe, starting to feel some impact from the recent launch of Martin Harris’ new retail concept, Tapi, which already has over twenty stores opened in the last six months. He is the son of Carpetright’s founder, Lord P Harris.

· The stock is still highly rated – The stock, which has steadily declined over the last six months, is still one of most highly rated ‘bricks and mortar’ retailers and is valued at a significant premium to peers such as Topps Tiles (TPT LN – HOLD – TP 160p) and Dunelm (DNLM LN – BUY – TP 980p). It is rated at 23.3x FY2016 our forecasts.
